answers.answer: See an endocrinologist that specializes in thyroids. Alot of them just do diabetes.Tell all that you have told here and .At the risk of  practising medicine with a license. you do sound hyopthyroid.If you need to make a list and take it to the doc.you need full panel labs run, T3 and T4 your free 3and 4 alot of folks get their adrenals checked as well and there is porbably something I have forgotten that someelse will post probably.Sorry about the avoiding medication but its really no big deal to a lttle pill to maintain the quality of life you are wanting.So make that appointment ASAP so you can start to feel better soon.Love Venora

question: I am 35, had 75% of my thyroid removed at 21 be/c of a tumor.  At the time, I didn't know it was a big deal and left the details to my parents.  I was told 25% is the minimum function before needing medication.  Originally thought to be cancer- my Dr. took all that was connected to the tumor.  I have not taken any medication and get my blood checked every few yrs- levels have been fine.  Now I have severe kidney pain (could be something else- in that area) gaining weight/loosing muscle texture, and having trouble regulating body temperature at night.  I was told tyroid levels could be checked all together- giving you a false sense of "normal" levels.  I really want to avoid medication if I can (at least before having children).  The kidney pain is getting harder to deal with- it seems many here are dealing with the same thing w/out Dr's knowing how to treat them.  What type of Dr. do I see? Urologist?  Any feedback?
title: What's going on with my tyroid? Where do I get help?
